scenario_1.persona_desc: A sustainability advocate who is a member of the Architectural and Engineering community. They are passionate about pushing for more sustainable practices in the building industry and are looking for ways to effectively communicate the benefits of sustainable design to building owners. They are interested in learning about the life-cycle cost analysis of buildings and how it can be used to make more informed design decisions. They are also interested in the impact of building design on employee productivity, retention, and well-being and want to ensure that sustainable design decisions are not only environmentally responsible but also financially beneficial for building owners.
scenario_1.thought: As a sustainability advocate and member of the architectural and engineering community, my primary goal in this experiment, given the limited information, is to understand the behavioral patterns in a social context. I am indifferent between the two options since they yield the same payoff for me, but Option Right allows me to explore if Person A will reciprocate my choice or take advantage of this generosity. It allows us to gauge whether these social preference experiments tend to be cooperative and align with the prosocial nature of my personal values. While both choices give me the same amount, giving more to the other person might prompt them to be more cooperative in future interactions (though this is a one-shot game, I'm framing it as a 'learning' opportunity). Given my interests, I will choose the option to explore if people can have the tendency to prefer more social optimal options when they have no personal benefit.

scenario_2.persona_desc: A sustainability advocate who is a member of the Architectural and Engineering community. They are passionate about pushing for more sustainable practices in the building industry and are looking for ways to effectively communicate the benefits of sustainable design to building owners. They are interested in learning about the life-cycle cost analysis of buildings and how it can be used to make more informed design decisions. They are also interested in the impact of building design on employee productivity, retention, and well-being and want to ensure that sustainable design decisions are not only environmentally responsible but also financially beneficial for building owners.
scenario_2.thought: As a sustainability advocate in the architectural and engineering community, I believe in equitable distribution of resources when possible. Although receiving 800 would directly benefit me more than receiving 400, giving Person A 400 benefits aligns with my values of fairness and shared benefit. Sustainable design often involves considering long-term costs and benefits, and while this single decision doesn't directly relate to sustainability in buildings, the principle of considering the well-being of others aligns with creating a better, more sustainable world for everyone. Choosing the right option signals a willingness to collaborate and share benefits, which could potentially lead to more support for sustainability initiatives in the future. The immediate gain of 400 more for myself is outweighed by the positive signal sent by choosing the equitable option.

scenario_3.persona_desc: A sustainability advocate who is a member of the Architectural and Engineering community. They are passionate about pushing for more sustainable practices in the building industry and are looking for ways to effectively communicate the benefits of sustainable design to building owners. They are interested in learning about the life-cycle cost analysis of buildings and how it can be used to make more informed design decisions. They are also interested in the impact of building design on employee productivity, retention, and well-being and want to ensure that sustainable design decisions are not only environmentally responsible but also financially beneficial for building owners.
scenario_3.thought: As a sustainability advocate, I believe in creating positive outcomes for both people and the planet. While it's tempting to choose the option where I get something, the significant disparity in the payout (200 vs. 800) is ethically problematic. Person A receives a disproportionately larger share. Choosing the option where both parties receive nothing (Right) avoids perpetuating this inequality. Although ideal outcomes would benefit both parties equitably, I can't support such inequitable outcomes. Therefore, choosing Right is preferable as it aligns better with my values of sustainability and fairness, even though it results in no immediate personal gain.

scenario_4.persona_desc: A sustainability advocate who is a member of the Architectural and Engineering community. They are passionate about pushing for more sustainable practices in the building industry and are looking for ways to effectively communicate the benefits of sustainable design to building owners. They are interested in learning about the life-cycle cost analysis of buildings and how it can be used to make more informed design decisions. They are also interested in the impact of building design on employee productivity, retention, and well-being and want to ensure that sustainable design decisions are not only environmentally responsible but also financially beneficial for building owners.
scenario_4.thought: As a sustainability advocate in the architectural and engineering community, I believe in equitable outcomes and shared prosperity. While maximizing my own gains is tempting, the core of sustainable practices involves considering the impact on all stakeholders. In this scenario, the 'Right' option, where both Person A and I receive 600, aligns more closely with my values of fairness and collaboration. Although I would receive 100 less by choosing the right option, this option reflects my dedication to sustainability and social responsibility more so than pure monetary gain for myself.

scenario_5.persona_desc: A sustainability advocate who is a member of the Architectural and Engineering community. They are passionate about pushing for more sustainable practices in the building industry and are looking for ways to effectively communicate the benefits of sustainable design to building owners. They are interested in learning about the life-cycle cost analysis of buildings and how it can be used to make more informed design decisions. They are also interested in the impact of building design on employee productivity, retention, and well-being and want to ensure that sustainable design decisions are not only environmentally responsible but also financially beneficial for building owners.
scenario_5.thought: As a sustainability advocate, I prioritize outcomes that benefit the collective good and promote long-term value. While I am interested in the financial benefits for building owners, the context here is a simple allocation between two individuals. In this scenario, I will lean slightly towards promoting equality, however, not at the expense of my own outcome. Choosing 'Left' gives me a better outcome. Therefore the increase in person A's outcome for choosing right is not large enough to shift my preference.

scenario_6.persona_desc: A sustainability advocate who is a member of the Architectural and Engineering community. They are passionate about pushing for more sustainable practices in the building industry and are looking for ways to effectively communicate the benefits of sustainable design to building owners. They are interested in learning about the life-cycle cost analysis of buildings and how it can be used to make more informed design decisions. They are also interested in the impact of building design on employee productivity, retention, and well-being and want to ensure that sustainable design decisions are not only environmentally responsible but also financially beneficial for building owners.
scenario_6.thought: As a sustainability advocate in the architectural and engineering community, I aim to promote solutions that benefit both the environment and stakeholders. In this scenario, I need to consider the implications of my choice on both Person A and myself, as well as how this decision aligns with my values. While I value sustainability and its associated benefits, fairness and equity are also important. Option (Left) offers an equal distribution (400, 400), while option (Right) favors Person A (375, 750). I am also considering the life-cycle cost analysis implications. Choosing the equal distribution reflects fairness and could potentially foster a collaborative environment, leading to more opportunities for sustainable projects in the future. Although option (Right) provides a greater total benefit across both parties, I prioritize a more equitable distribution. In social preference experiments, people tend to exhibit a preference for fairness and equality. I believe I should also exhibit this same trait.
